reviewText:
I played this game for hundreds of hours as a child and it's great to see it working again (the game is notorious for poor hardware support).
For a 13 year old game it holds up fairly well, although it does have several usability quirks that stand out such as build and info menus only closing when you press the X button rather than clicking anywhere off the menu as is much more common these days. Selecting moving vehicles can be a pain as well and so selecting your trucks from the vehicle status menu is advised.
Unlike many of the transport tycoon simulators out there, IG2 lets you manage the production of goods from start to finish. Each factory, mine, farm, refinery and so on, have their own production levels which change depending on the availability of resources. In other words, a ranch in grasslands produces more milk than one on a beach. This makes production more complicated as you add more stages of manufacturing before reaching a final product but the financial rewards are worth it. You also get to set the price of the products and place your stores in key locations to manage demand. Always make sure the demand is slightly higher than supply to prevent buildups of unsold goods in your storage areas. You can also export goods overseas for a reduced profit but the demand is always high. The range of goods available to export is slim though, conversely you can import goods for a higher price but without the hastle of producing it yourself.
As the game goes on you unlock a vast range of products and vehicles from inflatable dinghies to luxury cars. The number of options is impressive but may leave players feeling overwhelmed with choices that often won't make much difference.
One area the game does disappoint I feel is the transport side, although you can choose from lorries, trains, planes and ships there are few circumstances where the lorries aren't the best option, even over large distances. You don't get to set their route either so you can't choose to avoid a busy downtown area in lieu of the empty country road you just built. With trains you do get to choose which tracks to take, but you don't get to choose which platform they use and with a maximum of 2 tracks in and out of each station (2 per side if the trains turn around rather than passing through) bottlenecks at your large stations are an issue that has long since been solved on other transport sims.

It is disappointing that this remains one of the best games in the genre, it is a good game certainly, but there are lots of little issues you feel would not exist if they remade the game today. I would also advise caution when buying as it will not play on many computers. I have owned six PCs over the years and this game has only worked on two of them. This version does appear to work better than the original with the Nvidia patch, but do not be surprised if you have to ask for a refund. It's a shame that such a classic can't be enjoyed by a wider audience.

(It works for me on an Nvidia GTX 970 and on my GTX 770, both on Windows 10, since the issues seems to be graphics related you should be OK with either of these)

reviewText:
A nice optimization game based around producing, transporting, and selling various goods.

Pros:
- Tons of industries, products, and resources. Lots of transportation options.
- Very little guessing with the products. Lots of graphs and statistics tell you exactly how much of a product will be produced and consumed at each factory/store. This really helps optimizing.
- In-game wiki describes each product, where it is made, where it is sold, and what it takes to make.

Cons:
- Graphics are outdated (early 90s sprites). This doesn't really bother me a ton, but it could bother others.
- You never miss something until it's gone: the interface is outdated. Specifically, there is no time dilation (faster/slower) or pause. There is no view rotation which can make hooking up roads/rails difficult.
- The range of their buildings should be rebalanced. I find myself constantly either kicking myself or just taking dynamite to things because they are just out of range. Often by just one or two squares.

Nitpicks:
- They skimped on their English translator. You get the gist of what they're conveying, but it is off-putting. Names aren't exact so if you look for one thing, it's often called something else (though similar enough).
- Trains need brains. Even with two rails, they often go down the same side and slow each other down.

Edit: Found on the forums that + increases speed and - decreases. P" will pause. Still marking them down for not showing key bindings in the options or something. Who knows what other keys I'm missing?"
voteText: 15 of 17 people (88%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
I had the original box version of this. Got it back when I was a kid.
The box version would not run on modern PCs, but this steam version does run. I had only one crash. I guess the Devs did an ok job on remastering the game.

The game sets you up in a role of an entrepeneur, you decide what your company will produce and sell. Sadly there is no simulation of inter-company trade.
Eg. You could focus on being a supermarket.
You grow your own fruit orchard, have a dairy farm, and makes wine to sell in your own chain of stores.
You adjust prices of your goods and the demand-supply curve will adjust to your price. City grows overtime as you open new types of stores in the city (growth is VERY slow).
You must control all three sectors of business (Produce. Manufacture, and Retail) and also manage logistics for your goods.

It is good to play in campaign mode, deadlines forces you to make difficult choices, as your finances are limited and must be used in the most efficient manner. Eg. Would I set up a new production line (costs millions) next to a big city or would I buy a new cargo ship to supply that huge city across the map with goods made elsewhere? Would the transport cost break even or make a good return on investment?
My advice is to start slow and do not grow too fast.

The system is fairly simple when you get used to the quirky controls of the game.
Warning: The ESC button returns you to the main menu.

---------------------------------------------------------------------

7.5/10

It's a good simulator, but it's not the best.
It's a good test of macro management skill.
It does not promote varying play-style, you will find one working formula and probably stick to it.

reviewText:
Fantastic game!  I owned this on disc many years ago, and I have not been disapointed with this re-release, which enables you to run the game in full HD.  It is unfortunate that others have experienced problems when running the game - I have had no such issues (NVIDIA GTX 660, Windows 10).  I would advise those individuals to try again with the latest verison as a couple of patches have been released since launch.

Before starting the campaign, I recommend completing the three tutorial missions.  If you happen to close a dialog by mistake, which I did find frustrating at times, most can be re-opened from the message window (mail icon in the bottom left of the screen).

As for the campaign itself, I cannot comment much at this time as I have not been playing the game for long.  However, I remember playing the original game for many hours and finding it highly enjoyable.

In summary, highly recommend for those who have not experienced Industry Giant II before and for those fond of the original game who have always wanted a version that would work on a modern PC in full HD.

reviewText:
This is a great game which was made many years ago, and is one of my favorites once again. That being said there is an error (info below was from launch date; think they may have fixes this now. Compatability mode is often used for older games) which you may get when starting this game, and here is how to fix it:

Here is how to run this game when you get the graphics card error
Go to where this local game is stored on your computer. On mine it was:

C:\Program Files (x86)\Steam\steamapps\common\Industry Giant 2

Next rigth click on the file Ig2(underscore)AddOn (It won't let me type underscore on here it looks sort of like the minus key.)

Next click properties

Click compatability

Check run this administrator, and click run this program in compatability mode for: Windows 98/Windows ME.

Now run your game.
Also once you start a  game go to options, and turn off the videos as videos can cause crashes to the desktop.

The Good:
Very fun game based on transporting resources/products around and manufacturing/selling them. This is one of my favorites of all time. If you like business type games, this could easily be one of your favorites.

Cities grow

Ok graphics; remember this game came out originally in like 2002. :)

The Bad:
Have to run this in Windows 98/ME compatability.

Graphics a little outdated

reviewText:
This is how business simulations / management games should be: Lot's of stuff to do, to create, many choices what stuff you want to produce. Micromanagement is also a big deal in this game. If you ever wanted to create your own business while experience freedom of choice in finally doing it, you're gonna love this game.

Industry Giant 2 on Steam is a HD version of the classic game made in the early 2000s. It works perfectly fine on Win7 and I guess it does also on Win8 and above.

The game itself contains several campaigns with different difficulties and also a tutorial of how to play the game. Of course there is still a sandbox-mode without any goals where you can just run your enterprise. You start between 1900 and newer dates and can experience everything that comes with it: technologic advantages and possibilities. For example if you start in 1900 most of your business might be farming and stuff, while in the 50's you can produce sunmilk, boats, vendingmachines, bottles and other stuff.

The only thing I really dislike is the fact that you can't switch to the optionsmenü during the game. If you press ESC the game will end while creating an automatic savefile and will then show you the mainmenu where you can change your graphic and audio options. This can be annoying sometimes.

The price itself for such an old game is pretty high, despite the unique high quality it has for a business simulation game if you compare it with newer ones (which do not exist, sadly). You should buy it during a sale or if it's included in the Humble Bundle or something similar.

reviewText: Many people have been complaining about various compatability issues, telling others to not buy the game. The fact is, on some PC's it runs better than on others. From what I've heard about the developers, these various bugs may or may not get fixed. However, my PC runs the game just fine, and, to me, it is very playable and enjoyable in its current state. I would suggest buying the game and, if you have problems with it, simply return it. As I've seen, there seems to be no way to tell if the game will run on your system or not. It's not all NVidia graphics cards, which I use, its not later versions of windows, I'm currently on 10. Just try the game out and hopefully you can get the unique experience that I've been looking for in a game for a long time.\n\nThe game itself reminds me of Anno in that you have to set up production chains and turn products into other products. What was missing for me from Anno was the ability to just focus on the business aspect of the game. No diplomacy, no ecobalance, just making products. Now to be fair, I am a nerd. I like to see efficiency and to make small numbers get larger. If you don't like working with numbers, this game might not be for you. I for one like looking at my cow farm and deciding that I can run it at 75% efficiency to supply demand, or making the perfect ratio of wheat farms to donut factories. Hopefully the developers will keep their promises, fixing bugs and even adding multiplayer. I've even heard talk of a sequel, so I would be very excited to see a modernazation of this classic.

reviewText:
Although it's advertised to work on Windows 7, 8 and 10, some people have problems with this game. There are a couple of fixes mentioned on the forum that seem to work for most people, but be aware that you'll probably have to spend 5 or 10 minutes getting the game to work, as I had to do as well. This is an old game after all (released 2002), and wasn't developed to be compatible with our modern hardware.

The game itself is what I consider somewhat of a classic. Even though the Jowood games catalogue consists of relatively obscure titles like Traffic Giant, Transport Giant, and Hotel Giant, I think they have made some of the greatest classic tycoon-genre games ever made (apart from the *real* classics of course - you know which ones I mean).

IG2 combines goods transportation (similar to their other game Transport Giant) with industry and production management, and the result is a pretty fun game that, even though it shows its age in a number of places, will keep fans of the genre entertained for a decent amount of time.

To me it's worth its current discounted price (12€), to get to play a more or less fixed up" version of a game that I used to play a lot of. Without the nostalgia I would probably find it just a bit overpriced
date: especially the full price (15€) I think is pushing it for an old game like this. But it's definitely still a fun game
recommended: no matter how old it is."

reviewText:
Little mixed on this one so I will start with the good.

The good.

It runs with a little bit of life support aka windows compatibility but the devs said they are working on it (They really should have tested this first before releasing).

Supports 1080 60Hz the game might go higher but that’s all my screens can do.

The game itself is a great industry sim game still looks good in its old age just animations are not very smooth at times.

Easy to run no need to install any mods and change configs just install and run kinda.

The bad

Requires you to set windows to compatibility mode for it to even run (Should have been fixed before release)

They have taken the mod that has existed for the original game and just done some patch work on it, (You can tell as the mod changed the gold bars to gold fish for some reason this also occurs in this version and by the UI in the main menu) but they did fix the issue that the size of the train stations changed so some credit is due.

No multiplayer simple really they could have patched the game to use steam servers or just have direct IP connections but nope it all been removed that would have made it great.

A few graphical issues with the game when it comes to scrolling around the map and misaligned images in the ui.

No editor they really should provide this it makes the game much more fun and can make you enjoy it for longer.
Sound issues if you turn down the volume of the game sound effects and the music will change to full randomly can be very annoying.

Overpriced little work has gone in to this game from the devs poor testing and only small issues fixed

Overall I recommend the game itself as it is a great game but unless you want it on steam don’t get it on steam it is overpriced for its current state and if you already have the disc or gamergate version then don’t bother unless you want less hassle to play the game.

Hope this helps people and the devs and if the devs needs more info on the issues I found ask :).

reviewText:
This game actually doesn't run all that smooth on my high end laptop. Now, it runs without the crashing and graphic issues which other reviewers report.

Never the less, it was very easy for me to adjust to the game's low frame rate, only took a minute or two. The game itself is very enjoyable, it has a good selection of production, sale and transport methods to begin with, a nice early game, the mid game introduces much more complicated production chains, which you can however ignore if you prefer simpler production chains. As of writing this review, I have not gotten to the late game yet.

I would also not be too quick in comparing it with OpenTTD, as some reviewers seem to do. The similarities between the games are merely that they are 2D isometric games which feature vehicles. The base game of OpenTTD focuses on transporting one of about 10 different goods with very simple production chains, this game features complex production chains and much more flexible vehicles, which allow you a much greater ability to plan efficient routes (For example a truck can transport one good one way and another the other way)

Overall I think you should try the game out. As other reviewers pointed out, there is the chance it might not run on your computer, however if that proves to be the case you can just take advantage of Steam's refund policy.

reviewText:
First time played 10 years ago.
And till this day i played this game non-stop. Atleast 1 time in week.
After JoWood Productions bancrupt i thought all source files was destroyed.
But miracle happened and game lives again.

Little sad we dont have LAN or INTERNET mode.
But i hope to see this in the feature.

Game is amazing. Not hard, easy to learn. Many product variations.
You can create mods (Create new buildins, products,  vehicles)
You can create maps (just download from JoWood website, use waybackmachine website)

-----------
Jau gan ilga laiką žaidžiu šį žaidimą. Mažiausiai 10 metų. Žaisdavau mažiausiai 1 kartą į savaitę visą šį laiką.
Turiu rusišką CD, pirkau iš internetinės svetainės virtualią žaidimo kopiją, o dabar ir iš steam.
Kai bankrutavo JoWood Productions galvojau, kad žaidimas visam laikui liks užmarštį.
Neatsirado jokių kompanijų kurios norėtų apsiimti žaidimo perpirkimu ir tobulinimo, to pasekoje dauguma manė jog žaidimo svarbiausi source kodai buvo sunaikinti.
Bet įvyko stebuklas ir štai vokiečių kompanija po šitiek metų sugebėjo įgyti teises į šio žaidimo vardą.

Per pora savaičių išėjo svarbiausi atnaujinimai, kurie pataisė kritines klaidas.
To pasekoje dabar visi su naujausiom vaizdo kortom gali paleisti šį žaidimą be jokių problemų!
Ko nesugebėjo padaryti JoWood per daugelį metų!

Žinoma gaila, kad kad nėra multiplayer modo (LAN arba Internet), bet kolkas galima palaukti ir pasimėgauti Single-Player rėžimu. Jeigu vienam nuobodu, tuomet žaiskite prieš kompiuterio valdomas kompanijas.

Žaidimas tikrai geras. Ir kaip turbūt supratote - vienintelis ir nepabostantis.
Tai ne šaudyklė ar super sunkus strategas. Tai ekonominis simuliatorius kurį išmoksite be didelio vargo.
Labai daug produktų ir pasirinkimo laisvės kur statyti ar ką daryti.

Galite net sukurti modus (Sukurti naujus pastatus, produktus ar mašinas)
Galite sukurti savo žemėlapį (Atsisiūsti galite iš JoWood oficialios svetainės naudodami waybackmachine svetainę)

Rekomenduoju.

reviewText:
I am pretty sure I have never posted a review on here but felt compelled to do so for this game. I have loved this game ever since it came out 13 years ago and was really disappointed when even with all the online fixes, patches and workarounds I could find, I could not get it to work on my new pc or laptop.

I emailed the devs last year who said they were working on a version that would work with modern day computer's and their operating systems, but did not see anything further.

Then yesterday I see it drop on steam and immediately by it whilst it was on sale at £8 and I was upset to learn it still wouldn't work. Read some forums and tried a few workarounds including various different compatibility modes, but no dice.

I shut down my pc and rebooted and just as I was about to send an email to the devs, venting my frustration and requesting assistance or an eta on a fix, I decided to boot the game again (with no compatibility modes turned on), so that I could get the error code and Boom, worked first time and worked flawlessly all evening last night.

So to all who buy this game wanting it to work, try the workarounds, shut down and reboot your pc to try and make it work, you never know your luck. The fact it does work though on my PC which has an overlocked i7, GTX 780 ti, Windows 7 pro 64 bit, shows that there has been progress in making this game compatible with modern day PCS.

Unfortunately it does appear that its not universally working so yes its a risk, but if you played this game in the past and enjoyed it as much as I did, its worth the risk especially with the steam refund policy that now exists.

reviewText:
EDIT: The devs apparently have patched the game and for me now i dont have to run the game in Compatibility Mode! Im on Win7 64bit with an ATI R9 270 and it loads just fine and at 1080!

WOOHOO!! :)
_________________________________________________

Firstly, Do i recommend this game? well, ATM, I will say Yes! It looks great and while I have only done the tutorials and not put much time into it, it looks like it will be an awesome time sink! :)

Now, on to the part that nearly forced me to not recommend the game!

Along with may others, I had the crash issue as the game loads! Usually an instant thumb down!

BUT, For me the issue was fixed simply by finding the game .exe file (\Steam\steamapps\common\Industry Giant 2)  and then setting the Compatibility Mode to Win Xp Sp3. By doing this the game loads just fine and it loads in 1080!!
The only other Compatibilty mode it loaded for me was in Win95 but I couldnt change the resolution at all because it just crashed.

So, IF you have the game and it wont load, try what I posted and see if it works. A dev has said they are working on fixing the issue. I will update this review IF they fix it!

reviewText:
Had quite a few issues on launch, but the majority of problems are fixed now.

I always loved this game when it was first released, unfortunately, my last two computers haven't been able to run it off the disk. When I saw this had been re-released on steam, I read some reviews and was hesitant, because a lot of people had the same issue that I had with the disk copy. Eventually I gave in and got it, and honestly, I was very glad I did. Exactly the same as I remember, but able to run in my native screen resolution.

It's a great game for tycoon/management game fans, however it is over 13 years old, and it does show this with a lack of all continuity past 2002, where it becomes 'future predictions.' Regardless, it's an excellent game.

reviewText:
After many years of hanging on to my legacy PCI Graphic card just so I could enjoy this game. The Dev’s finally blew the sands of time off the code and resurrected a classic instead of re-inventing the wheel and adding corners to it like, most them do these days. It shows great restraint and a respect for titles that have paved the way in their genre. And yes they are dated by today’s standards but put into context of their time period, they were and still are brilliant. Even today very few titles or Dev’s come close to or exceed the mark left by the ones that came before it.

If you have ever play the original JoWood Game in 2002 and upgraded pc in 2004 and realized it won't work any more
Well you’re in luck as this now works on newer machines

Yes there are Bugs but still very playable, but is the nature of the beast. Considering the iphone / android you are using has more power then most of the PC's back then 700 MHz Pentium 3's and the like so most of the bugs would be from JoWood's code and there narrow vision of the world in 2 years time let alone 13
So hoping the new dev’s keeps this title going

reviewText:
The game is relativly fun and I think I would enjoy it if I could put it in a realoution thats 16:9 because I hate the black bars appart from that if you enjoyed OpenTTD then this is a more indepth version of this, the Price of it is OK I guess, it old as hell so I would rather it be around the £5 range but I guess £10 isnt too bad. Follow me instructions below if you have a issue with not being able to launch due to a graphics card error.

This is a Fix for the issue people are having with a graphics card error.

Its quite basic really, supprised people havent tryed it already.

Just to clarify I'm running a Nvidia GTX680 and can run the game.

OK now to the fix simply head into the games directory should look something like this C:\Program Files (x86)SteamLibrary\SteamApps\common\Industry Giant 2 and right click the file called i♥♥♥♥ddOn and run it in Windows 95 compatability mode and it will launch.

Because basically what the developer has done is just upload the origonal files to steam it is looking for a old graphics card and operating system, by tricking it with compatability mode the game runs fine, only issue I see is, is that there are no 16:9 resoloution options because as previously stated this is a old as hell game. Not a bad game its just old so bare with its quirks.

reviewText:
This game is a lot of fun.
It is a bit old but still a classic.
Of all the Tycoon style games I think this one is among the best. If you like Tycoon or business sims I think you will love this game.

The game allows you to move your goods by Road, Railroad, Air, and over the water ways. In addition to that you can setup your fields, factories, and warehouses in such a way that you don’t need a transport system if they are close to each other.

The world changes as the city’s and town grow as you meet there needs.

You can fine tune your production to be a lean efficient business, lowering and raising your industries output and changing wages paid to your workers.

I am running it with no issues on Windows 10.

reviewText: One of the greats. Don't let the user reviews bum you out, if you play a lot of tycoon games then you'll appreciate this one. Ran fine on my modern system, the U.I is a little fiddly and theres no way to view/change controls (I know speed up is in there somewhere), but overall its a classic with a lot of variety that can eat up a lot of hours.

reviewText:
I can't believe it.  This was one of my favorite games of all time.  They had a weird glitch where it was incompatible with GeForce cards.  Like, ALL GeForce cards.  Since the existence of the GeForce I haven't been able to play this game.  I'm so happy I finally have it!

Now on to the actual game.

This game is a transport and economics sim with a very simplified mechanic.  Make goods, move goods, sell goods.  Trains are very forgiving- there's no signals or collisions here.  The early missions are pretty easy but later on there are some really cool interesting tasks.

I don't know if it holds up with age, I just know I love it.

reviewText: Oh... my first love, when it comes to Tycoon-like simulations. Beside those 18 hours atm of writing this review, I probably spent 100s of hrs more almost 15 years ago... man! Many times I blindly checked to see if the game exists on Steam, and one time, out of nowhere - BAM! There it was. In HD and everything! I didn't really even expect it!\n\nYou may find some much more helpful reviews here, but I just want to give one thumb up more for the game and the devs and recommend it to all Tycoon-Sim lovers. It might sound stupid, but I think some ways of thinking that are helping me in life I learned from this game. Once I saw a friend of mine making a mistake and crashing his small business (irl) before it even started and spending all of his savings, and I was like: poor ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥
date: why didn't you play IG2 for a day or two before starting with this little adventure
recommended: you would have planned better ahead!?".\n\nOther than some graphic glitches I didn't experience any major
voteText: playing on Win 10."
